document.docAuthor: Luo, Xinyu, Li, Fasheng, Ma, Yanfang & Cai, Wanzhi
document.docTitle: Cacopsylla (Hepatopsylla) cinereosignata Luo, Li, Ma & Cai, 2012, sp. n.
document.masterDocTitle: A revision of Chinese pear psyllids (Hemiptera: Psylloidea) associated with Pyrus ussuriensis

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A revision of Chinese pear psyllids (Hemiptera: Psylloidea) associated with Pyrus ussuriensis

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 41–43 .
Cacopsylla ( Hepatopsylla ) cinereosignata
sp. nov.
, nymph. 41 . Overall view, left half shows dorsal aspect, right half shows ventral aspect; 42 . ventral surface of caudal plate; 43 . tarsal arolium and claws. Scale: for 17, 0.6 mm; for 18, 0.2 mm; for 19, 0.075 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
5 th instar nymph.
Coloration: For specimens preserved in absolute ethanol and not dissected. Body general color yellow. Sclerites yellow to dark brown. Compound eyes crimson. Apical 2 / 3 of antennal segment 7 black.

Material examined. Holotype : male, dry mounted,
China , Gansu,
Zhujiahetan, Sanshilipu, Hezheng, on
Pyrus ussuriensis
,
10 .ix. 2011
, Ma Yanfang.

Paratypes :
8 male
,
11 female
with same data as holotype , along with numerous nymphs.
Non-paratypic specimens: Additional specimens from the same series are preserved in absolute ethanol.
Etymology. From Latin, cinereus = grey, signatus = marked. This species is named after its obscure light grey oblong marking in cell cu 2 .

Remarks. This species displays conspicuous intraspecific variation in the shape of cell cu 1 , which in some individuals is taller than in
Fig. 40
, exceeding the shape of that of
C. chinensis
summer form (
Fig. 28
).
